_prev_prog_3.Description: The Keyera Energy, Shelton Terminal facility is located at West 1033, State Route 108 in Shelton, Washington.  This facility provides for the transfer of liquefied propane under pressure from stationary (detached from locomotive) pressure tank/rail cars to stationary aboveground storage tanks.  Product is moved to storage tanks using a fixed railcar unloading system via pressure differential, and pumped from storage tanks to transport trucks and trailers using liquid transfer pumps.  A Process Safety Management program has been prepared and implemented at the terminal. This program uses a systematic approach to evaluate the whole process.  Each process has been evaluated as a separate entity.  Various emergency shutdown and backup lines of defense have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals. Every five years or sooner if warranted, processes will be evaluated and strengthened where required to assure their effectiveness.  Keyera Energy has developed standard operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information. Operating procedures for designated processes will be reviewed by the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) team, engineering staff, and operating personnel to ensure that they are accurate and provide practical instructions on how to actually carry out job duties safely. Keyera Energy has developed and implemented an emergency action plan to facilitate the prompt response, notification and evacuation of employees due to an unwanted release of propane.  The site emergency planning and response procedures describe the actions to be taken by all responding personnel to potential emergency situations at the Keyera Energy Shelton terminal.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at our facility:
Keyera is committed to the safety of its workers, the public, and the environment.  Its accidental release policy is an integrated approach, involving employee participation, management practices, written procedures, and training.  Keyera has developed a comprehensive propane accident prevention program considering all aspects of process operation and maintenance.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the Shelton Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency. We also maintain incipient stage fire fighting equipment on site. This facility complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LP-Gas storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  The facility came online in 2009. 

A description of our facility and the regulated substances handled: 
This facility is a bulk terminal storing LPG for resale to retail propane dealers.  The facility consists of storage tanks, rail cars and piping.
Storage Tanks*
Four (4) 30,000-gallon aboveground storage tanks totaling 120,000 gallons or approximately 504,000 pounds.
*Tanks are not filled beyond 85% capacity, which is 102,000 gallons or     428,400 pounds.

Rail Cars*
Six (6) maximum unattached 33,000-gallon railcars may be on-site at a time for a maximum total of 198,000 gallons or 837,600 pounds.
*Tanks are not filled beyond 85% capacity, which is 168,300 gallons or     706,800 pounds.

Piping
All piping contents will be a portion of the initial railcar or storage tank capacity.

Total Maximum Inventory = 270,300 gallons or 1,135,368 pounds.

There are both manual and automatic emergency shutdown systems on all LPG equipment at the site.

The worst-case and alternative release scenarios:
Our worst-case scenario is failure of the four 30,000-gallon storage tanks when the storage tanks are filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% at 60F), resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. It a

ssumes all the propane is released and ignited.  No passive mitigation system is considered.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite to 0.6 miles, and public receptors are within the distance to the endpoint.  Keyera has multiple safeguards in place which make this scenario very unlikely.  Our alternative release scenario involves a propane release from a product line at the loading skid over a 2-minute period at a rate of 100 pounds per minute.  An excess flow check valve is the active mitigation system considered in this scenario.  A total of 200 pounds of propane is ignited, resulting is a vapor cloud fire.  This would extend and estimated 0.03 miles.  The resulting distance to the endpoint extends offsite.  The only  public receptors within the distance to the endpoint is the business to the east.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
This facility complies with EPAA?s accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The propane system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state law.

Five-year accident history: 
Keyera Energy, Inc. acquired the facility in December 2009.  We have never had an accident involving propane that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or shelterings in-place.  To the best of our knowledge no such incident occurred prior to acquisition by Keyera Energy, Inc.

The emergency response program:
Keyera Energy has developed a emergency action plan specific to this facility. In the event of an emergency involving our propane system, it is our policy to notify the Shelton Fire Department and request that they help respond to the emergency.  We also have trained employees in incipient stage fire fighting.  We have coordinated our response plans with the fire department; members of the fire department have been provided the opportunity to visit our facili

ty and inspect our propane storage system.  

Planned changes to improve safety:
Keyera Energy, Inc. will continually strive for safety improvement.  Periodic process safety inspections will be conducted followed with timely response.
